Graphical abstract This review provides a comprehensive understanding of the thriving electrocatalytic nitrate/nitrite reduction to ammonia under ambient conditions, and outlines the challenges and possible prospects in the future. Ammonia (NH3) is a multifunctional compound that is an important feedstock for the agricultural and pharmaceutical industries and attractive energy storage medium. At present, NH3 synthesis is highly dependent on the conventional Haber–Bosch process that operates under harsh conditions, which consumes large quantities of fossil fuels and releases a large amount of carbon dioxide. As an alternative, electrosynthesis is a prospective method for producing NH3 under normal temperature and pressure conditions. Although electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction to ammonia has attracted considerable attentions, the low solubility of N2 and high N≡N cracking energy render the achievements of high NH3 yield rate and Faradaic efficiency difficult. Nitrate and nitrite (NO x −) are common N-containing pollutants. Due to their high solubilities and low dissociation energy of N=O, NO x − are ideal raw materials for NH3 production. Therefore, electrocatalytic NO x − reduction to NH3 (eNO x RR) is a prospective strategy to simultaneously realise environmental protection and NH3 synthesis. This review offers a comprehensive understanding of the thriving eNO x RR under ambient conditions. At first, the popular theory and mechanism of eNO x RR and a summary of the measurement system and evaluation criteria are introduced. Thereafter, various strategies for developing NO x − reduction catalysts are systematically presented and discussed. Finally, the challenges and possible prospects of electrocatalytic NO x − reduction are outlined to facilitate energy-saving and environmentally friendly large-scale synthesis of NH3 in the future. Keywords Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction Electrocatalytic nitrite reduction Ammonia synthesis Pollutant removal Electrosynthesis 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is not only an important raw material in the agricultural and pharmaceutical industries but also a highly efficient energy storage medium [1–3]. NH3 demonstrates the advantages of a high bulk energy density (3000 Wh kg−1), energy saving (when compared with the case of H2 decomposition), and convenient transportation and storage [4–7]. Presently, NH3 synthesis is performed using the traditional Haber–Bosch process that utilises Fe/Ru-based catalysts to convert N2 and H2 into NH3 under high-temperature (400–500 °C) and high-pressure conditions (150–300 atm) [8–10]. It is an energy-intensive process that not only consumes a considerable amount of energy but also releases a large amount of CO2 [11–14]. Additionally, complex infrastructure is required for the Haber–Bosch process. Although this process has been extensively optimised in the past century, the problems associated with this process are still not solved [15–18]. Therefore, developing economical and environmentally friendly methods of NH3 production is of significant importance. As an alternative green NH3 synthesis method, electrosynthesis that utilises renewable energy under mild conditions has been widely investigated by researchers [19–22]. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction to ammonia (eNRR) has attracted substantial attention because it provides the possibility of directly utilising water and air for NH3 production under mild conditions [23–27]. Although considerable efforts have been made by researchers for a long time to optimise this reaction, the Faradaic efficiency (FE) and NH3 yield rate (R NH3) of eNRR cannot satisfy the commercial demands [28–31]. The low solubility of N2 in water results in insufficient nitrogen transport, which is the main reason for the low N2 reduction rate of eNRR [32–34]. In contrast, numerous protons on the catalyst surface facilitate the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [35–37]. The theoretical reaction potential of eNRR is close to that of HER (0.092 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE)), rendering the competitive HER very severe [38,39]. Moreover, the high N≡N dissociation energy (941 kJ mol−1) under ambient conditions causes inferior eNRR performance [40–44]. Hence, industrial application of eNRR cannot be technically achieved. In comparison with eNRR, electrocatalytic NO3 −/NO2 − reduction to NH3 (eNO x RR) endows NH3 electrosynthesis with faster reaction rate. First of all, the higher solubilities of NO x − (x = 2 and 3) facilitate the contact of the catalyst surface with sufficient NO x − [45–47]. Then, the relatively lower energy of N=O (204 kJ mol−1) promotes the process of deoxygenation/hydrogenation [48–50]. Once more, the higher reaction theoretical potential of eNO x RR (0.69 V vs. RHE) renders eNO x RR more thermodynamically prone to occur than the case of eNRR [38]. Because of the larger standard reduction potential difference between eNO x RR and HER, eNO x RR effectively avoids interference from competitive HER. On the other hand, NO3 − is a common pollutant that primarily originates from the misuse of nitrogenous fertilizers, discharge of wastewater, and combustion of fossil fuels [49–55]. Additionally, NO3 − can be transformed into more toxic NO2 − by NO3 −-reducing bacteria in the human body, resulting in various serious diseases such as methemoglobinemia and cancer [56–59]. Considering economic benefits and environmental protection, NO3 − and NO2 − are ideal raw materials for NH3 production [60–62]. NO x − reduction to valuable NH3 not only effectively alleviates the energy crisis but also reduces environmental pollution caused by NO x − [63–65]. In this review, the progress in electrocatalytic NO x − reduction for the sustainable synthesis of the high value-added product NH3 is summarised (Fig. 1 ). At first, this review provides an overview of the possible mechanism underlying eNO x RR. Then, the measurement system and evaluation criteria for eNO x RR are systematically discussed. Moreover, the development strategies of eNO x RR catalysts are appropriately classified and introduced from the aspects of vacancy defects, heteroatom doping, alloying, single-atom catalysis active sites, and the construction of heterostructures, composites, and molecular catalysts. The principles of different development strategies regulating and affecting the catalyst performance are comprehensively explored. Finally, the current opportunities and challenges in electrocatalytic NO x − reduction are put forward. 2 Fundamental understanding of eNO x RR NO3 −/NO2 − reduction to NH3 is a complex eight-/six-electron transfer process, which may generate numerous reaction intermediates and products with valence states ranging from −3 to +5. Thus, understanding the mechanism of eNO x RR is significantly important for designing efficient electrocatalysts and improving their performances. The eNO x RR mechanism strongly depends on the reactant concentration and pH of the electrolyte. eNO3RR can be divided into two pathways: indirect autocatalytic and direct electrocatalytic reduction pathways (Figs. 2 and 3 ) [66–69]. The indirect autocatalytic reduction only occurs in strong acid electrolytes with high ion concentrations (1.0–4.0 M NO3 −). NO3 − is not a truly electroactive species and do not directly participate in electron transfer [70]. Different electroactive species can lead to two possible autocatalytic mechanisms: Vetter and Schmid mechanisms [68,69]. The electroactive species for the Vetter mechanism is NO2•, whereas that for the Schmid mechanism is NO+. NO2 and HNO2 are the final products of the Vetter and Schmid mechanisms, respectively. When the NO3 − concentration exceeds 4.0 M, the reactions do not involve electrochemical electron transfer; therefore, they cannot be considered as parts of the indirect autocatalytic reduction. The direct electrocatalytic reduction occurs at low NO3 − concentrations (<1 M). In most studies, eNO3RR is generally examined at low NO3 − concentrations. NH3/NH4 + and N2 are the most thermodynamically stable forms of N, particularly at pH between 6 and 9. NO3 −/NO2 − reduction to N2 is a five-/three-electron transfer process. Hence, N2 is a strong competitive product of NO x − reduction to NH3. The direct electrocatalytic reduction proceeds via two different pathways: atomic hydrogen and electron transfer reduction pathways. Initially, NO3 − is adsorbed on the catalyst surface, forming adsorbed state (ad) NO3 − (Eq. (1)). NO3 − adsorbs on metal surfaces via two-fold coordination, where NO3 − can coordinate with the metal surface via either one or two O atoms on Cu, Au, and Pt [71,72]. Both NO3 − and NO2 − demonstrate two-fold coordination to the Cu (100) surface, which promotes the cleavage of N=O bonds [73]. In the atomic hydrogen (H(ad)) reduction pathway, atomic H(ad) is produced by the Volmer process on the cathode surface (Eq. (2)) [74]. Atomic H exhibits strong reducibility; therefore, it can reduce many intermediate species such as adsorbed NO3 −, NO2 −, and NO (Eqs. (3)–(5)). Two N(ad) atoms can combine to generate N2. The calculated migration barrier of H(ad) is 0.10 eV, which is considerably lower than that of N(ad) (0.75 eV) [75]. Furthermore, N–H formation is more kinetically favoured than N–N formation [76]. Hence, NH3 formation (Eqs. (6)–(8)) is promoted due to the enhanced H(ad) adsorption. NO2 − is produced by the cracking of N–O (Eq. (9)), which proceeds via an electrochemical-chemical-electrochemical mechanism comprising three steps [77]. Reduction of NO3 − to NO2 − is regarded as the rate-determining step (RDS) of the overall process. In detail, NO3 − is reduced to an unstable nitrate dianion (NO3 2−) during initial electrochemical reduction (Eq. (10)). Then, NO3 2− is quickly hydrolysed via a homogeneous chemical reaction into nitrogen dioxide radical (NO2•) (Eq. (11)). Subsequently, NO2 − is formed via the second charge-transfer reaction of NO2• (Eq. (12)). Highly active NO2 − can produce adsorbed nitric oxide (NO(ad)) on the electrode surface according to Eq. Adsorption behaviour of NO(ad) can determine product selectivity and the following catalytic mechanisms: When NO(ad) is N-end adsorbed, NO(ad) is reduced via an electrochemical-electrochemical mechanism, which is a widely accepted mechanism for NH3 synthesis [78]. The electrochemical-electrochemical mechanism includes several continuous direct charge-transfer procedures. At first, HNO(ad) is formed when NO(ad) is reduced by an electron (Eq. (14)). Thereafter, the produced HNO requires an electron to generate H2NO(ad) (Eq. (15)). Additionally, charge transfer quickly reduces H2NO(ad) to hydroxylamine (NH2OH) (Eq. (16)), which can be protonated depending on pH (Eq. (17)). Finally, NH2OH is reduced to NH3 as the end product (Eq. (18). An equilibrium exists between ammonia and ammonium ion (Eq. (19)). In a large-scale eNO x RR, a certain amount of NH2OH may accumulate. NH2OH may be consumed and further generate N2 and N2O (Eqs. (20) and (21), respectively). Furthermore, two HNO molecules rapidly bind to each other to produce hyponitrous acid (H2N2O2) (Eq. (22)), which undergoes acid-catalysed decomposition in strong acid, generating N2O (Eq. (23)) [79]. Owing to the complexity and imperfect mechanism of eNO x RR, providing more in situ characterisation and theoretical calculation evidence is necessary to systematically explain the reaction mechanism for promoting further development of the reaction system and achieving new breakthroughs. 3 Measurement system and evaluation criteria for eNO x RR In the literatures, various parameters have been used to evaluate the performance of eNO x RR. To facilitate the comparison and screening of different catalysts, herein, a standard measurement procedure for activity evaluation is proposed (Fig. 5 ) [86,87]. 3.1 Electrochemical measurement procedure Electrochemical measurements are typically performed using a three-electrode system in an H-type cell. Control experiments should be conducted to ensure no contamination in the testing system. Contaminations from the atmosphere, equipment, and working electrode must be excluded. Electrocatalytic performance of catalysts can be preliminarily examined by cyclic voltammetry or linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in electrolytes with and without NO x −. The increase of current density in the electrolyte containing NO x − indicates the occurrence of eNO x RR. The measured potential range can be preliminarily obtained by analysing the LSV curves. Chronoamperometry tests should be repeated at least three times at each selected potential to confirm the repeatability of the results. Then, the corresponding performance parameters including R NH3, FE, selectivity, conversion rate, NH3 partial current density (j NH3), and energy efficiency (EE) of eNO x RR can be acquired. Generally, the more negative the specified potential, the higher conversion rate, while FE or selectivity exhibits a volcanic shape curve at different applied potentials. Therefore, the best electrocatalytic activity can be achieved at the optimal potential. Stability is one of the critical parameters for analysing catalyst performance. At the optimal potential, consecutive and long-term stabilities can be evaluated via multiple cyclic chronoamperometry experiments and continuous chronoamperometry tests, respectively. Fluctuation of R NH3, FE, NH3 selectivity (S NH3), or conversion rate of NO x − (C(NO x −)) within a reasonable range verifies excellent stability of the catalyst towards eNO x RR. To investigate the performance of catalysts, normalising their active sites is important, and the active sites can be evaluated by measuring the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of catalysts. Reasonable structure–activity relationships of outstanding catalysts can be acquired by comparing the standardised electrochemical results of different catalysts relative to ECSA. Electrochemical double layer capacitance is proportional to ECSA and surface roughness factor of electrocatalyst. Moreover, electronic conductivities of catalysts can be analysed via electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, where the charge-transfer resistances can be obtained from the Nyquist plots. Finally, isotope labelling experiments should be coupled with nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to verify that all the produced NH3 molecules originate from the electroreduction of NO x −. 3.2 Quantifications of possible products Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectrophotometry, ion chromatography (IC), gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC–MS), and 1H NMR spectroscopy can be used to quantify the reactants and several products. UV–vis spectrophotometry is a common and convenient method for quantifying the NO3 −, NO2 −, NH3/NH4 +, N2H4, and NH2OH concentrations. NO3 − can be directly determined because NO3 − exhibits UV absorption at 220 nm. As NO2 − demonstrates no absorption in the UV–vis region, a chromogenic agent is added to NO2 − to generate a purplish red substance that exhibits UV absorption at 540 nm. A mixture of phosphoric acid, p-aminobenzenesulfonamide, N-(1-naphthyl) ethylenediamine dihydrochloride, and ultrapure water is employed as the chromogenic agent. NH3 and NH4 + also do not demonstrate absorptions in the UV–vis region. The indophenol blue method can be utilised to determine NH3 or NH4 + as the absorbance of the produced indophenol blue can be measured at 655 nm. Nessler’s reagent is also suitable for NH3 detection, and absorbance of the generated yellowish-brown complex is measured at 420 nm. The Watt and Chrisp method is used to determine N2H4, in which a chromogenic agent is prepared by mixing para-(dimethylamino) benzaldehyde, ethanol, and concentrated hydrochloric acid. Absorbance of the resulting complex is evaluated at 455 nm. The detection agent for NH2OH is excess 8-quinolinol dissolved in ethanol and sodium carbonate solution. By mixing NH2OH and the detection agent, the absorbance of NH2OH is measured at 705 nm. IC is a reliable and simple method to measure NO3 −, NO2 −, and NH4 + concentrations; nevertheless, the samples need to be pre-processed to avoid damage to the instrument caused by organic matter or heavy metal ions. Gaseous products, for example, N2, NO, and N2O can be quantified by GC. NH4 + concentration can also be quantitatively determined via 1H NMR spectroscopy. Note that when the NH3 concentration is equal to or above 0.2 ppm, all routine detection methods can be employed for NH3 quantification. In contrast, when the NH3 concentration is less than 0.2 ppm, the choice of quantitative method depends on pH of the electrolyte after electrochemical measurement [88]. Therefore, two or more methods should be employed to quantify NH3/NH4 + concentrations to guarantee the reliability and accuracy of the data. 3.3 Performance evaluation parameters R NH3, FE, C(NO x −), NH3 selectivity, and stability are the primary performance evaluation parameters for eNO x RR. R NH3 per unit time and mass/area is the direct parameter for examining the performances of catalysts. FE describes the overall selectivity of an electrocatalytic process and is defined as the ratio of the actual consumed electrons towards a specific product to the theoretical consumed electrons [89]. Compared eNO x RR process with competitive HER, FE is the parameter for evaluating eNO x RR selectivity [90]. NH3 selectivity refers to the ratio of the amount of reactant consumed in NH3 production to the amount of reactant converted. R NH3 can be expressed by the following formulas.
