We hope that these strategies for developing electrocatalysts can enlighten valuable designs for electrocatalysts with excellent activities. 4.1 Vacancy defects Vacancy engineering plays an important role in electrocatalytic NO x − reduction. Introducing vacancy defects, such as oxygen [91], sulphur [92], phosphorus [93], and metal cation vacancies, into metal oxides is a significant strategy for adjusting the catalytic performances by modulating the electronic structures of catalysts, optimising the intermediate adsorption energies, and reducing the energy barriers. 4.1.1 Anion vacancies Oxygen vacancies (OVs) are the most common anion vacancies in transition metal (TM) oxides owing to their low formation energies [94]. OVs have been extensively used to improve the activities of catalysts in eNRR, HER, oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and oxygen reduction reaction; however, their application in eNO x RR is still in its infancy [95]. Actually, OVs can also play a crucial role in electrochemical NO3 −/NO2 − conversion. For example, the incorporation of OVs into TM oxides can accelerate the adsorption/activation of NO3 − because OVs can act as reactive sites for NO3 − adsorption and weaken the N–O bond of NO3 −. Furthermore, OVs can boost charge transfer and enhance the adsorption properties of the intermediates by altering the electronic structures of electrocatalysts. The OVs concentration can be adjust by chemical reduction (different reductants) and thermal treatment (different atmosphere or calcination temperatures) in which transitional metal cations are reduced to a lower valence state. TiO2− x with abundant OVs synthesised via H2 reduction demonstrated better activity and selectivity for NH3 when compared with those of pristine TiO2 [96]. TiO2− x exhibited higher current density in an electrolyte containing NO3 − (Fig. 6 a). Over time, the NO3 − concentration continuously declined, whereas the NH4 + concentration increased, indicating the reduction of NO3 − to NH4 + (Fig. 6b). Simultaneously, the NO2 − concentration initially increased and then decreased, revealing high selectivity of the catalyst for NH4 +. The adsorption energy of NO3 − on TiO2 (101) substantially decreased when the number of OVs increased from 0 to 2 in TiO2− x . Online differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) measurements and mechanistic studies revealed that OVs of TiO2− x were filled with the O atom of NO3 −, weakening the N–O bond and hindering the by-product formation, thus boosting FE and NH3 selectivity (Fig. 6c). In another work, Cu clusters loaded on defective TiO2 nanosheets (10Cu/TiO2−x ) were prepared [97]. Experimental results and theoretical investigations manifested that OVs promoted NO3 − adsorption and optimised the hydrogenation manner, thereby inhibiting by-product synthesis. An effective strategy to introduce OVs in catalysts is regulating the degree of structural disorder. C-supported RuO2 nanosheets with disordered structure were utilised to catalyse eNO3RR for NH3 production [98]. The improved catalytic ability (a high FE of 97.46% with a selectivity of 96.42%) originated from the disordered structure with rich OVs, which modulated the H affinity and d-band centre, leading to lower energy for the potential-determining step (PDS). Plasma treatment is an efficient technique to fabricate OVs on TM oxides. Daiyan et al. found that regulating the duration of the He plasma treatment could control the density of OVs on TM oxides [99]. Furthermore, the direct correlation between OV density and NH4 + yield on CuO (111) surface was investigated via mechanical calculations. The adsorption energy of NO3 − on the CuO (111) surface increased after the introduction of one OV into CuO (111). This adsorption energy significantly decreased with a further increase in the number of OVs from one to two and three (Fig. 6d), which indicated that “sufficient amount” of OVs facilitated NO3 − adsorption and therefore promoted eNO3RR for NH3 synthesis. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were conducted to confirm the generation and nature of OVs created on CuO during flame spray pyrolysis and subsequent plasma treatment. Theoretical computations were employed to obtain further insights into eNO 3 RR (Fig. 6e). Based on the combined results of in situ diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy (Fig. 6f) and mechanistic investigations, Gong et al. concluded that OVs and hydroxyl groups accelerated NO3 − adsorption and proton transfer [100]. Via Bader charge analysis (Fig. 6g and h), they observed that the polarisation charge density of the Cu site around OVs (10.78 e−) was much higher than that for pristine Cu (10.46 e−), suggesting that the extra electron induced by OVs stayed closer to the Cu site. The larger local charge density around the Cu site and upshifted Cu d-orbital enhanced charge transfer between the catalyst surface and intermediates, thus optimising the eNO3RR performance. Another effective strategy to introduce OVs is randomly replacing high valence metal ions with low valence metal ions. Du et al. revealed that the presence of OVs in pseudobrookite Fe2TiO5 (FTO) nanofiber enhanced the conductivity of FTO and led to substantially low free energy for NO3 − adsorption [101]. High-reducibility Fe3+ randomly replaced quadrivalent Ti4+, which tend to induce the formation of OVs. This FTO catalyst achieved high-efficiency NO3 − reduction and exhibited high activity in the conversion of NO2 − to NH3. Qiu et al. developed WO2 nanoparticles with numerous OVs (WO2/W) for effective synthesis of NH3 from NO2 − [102]. Computational simulation results proved that OVs significantly suppressed HER and side reactions, thereby guaranteeing excellent NH3 selectivity. The OV strategy was also applied by Zhao et al., and defect-enriched TiO2−x nanobelt array was proved as an efficient material for eNO2RR [103]. Other anion vacancies, including sulphur vacancies (SVs) and phosphorus vacancies (PVs), also demonstrate promising NO3 − conversion abilities. Tao et al. proposed an electric joule heating method to optimise SVs on Ni3Co6S8 (NCS) surface [92]. SVs were corroborated to tune electronic structure and facilitate the formation of *NO2, giving rise to an excellent R NH3 (2.388 mg h−1 cm−2) and selectivity (98.2%) at –0.4 V vs. RHE. In another study, Cu-doped SnS2 nanoflowers enriched with SVs were constructed [104]. Mechanistic studies indicated that SVs caused free electron transfer to Sn, thereby enhancing the adsorption capacity. Heterogeneous bimetallic phosphide (CoNi-Vp) rich in PVs was recently synthesised based on an O-doping strategy to trigger the generation of PVs [93]. Theoretical investigations revealed that PVs moved PDS of eNO3RR forward, which promoted the kinetic process. 4.1.2 Cation vacancies Recent studies have indicated that the constructing metal cation vacancies is another efficient method for improving the electrocatalytic properties of materials [105]. Introducing metal cation vacancies can tune the distribution of electrons and orbitals and increase the valence state of adjacent atoms, therefore reducing the energy barrier. Zhang et al. reported Au1Cu single-atom alloys (SAAs) with surface Cu vacancies (VCu-Au1Cu SAAs) [106]. Because of their weakest electron intensities, Cu vacancies appeared black (circled in white) in the coloured intensity map (Fig. 7 a). High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) intensity profile of the white-dotted box region (Fig. 7b) was obtained to reveal the Cu vacancies. The intensity data (Fig. 7c) confirmed that the Cu vacancies coexisted with isolated Au atoms. EPR measurements (Fig. 7d) and mechanical calculations demonstrated that the bifunctional Cu sites accelerated water activation, producing active *H for NO3 − hydrogenation and reducing the energy barrier of *NH3 desorption, thereby boosting the intrinsic performance. Yu et al. used a one-step hydrothermal method to synthesise a novel V–MoS2 electrocatalyst via defect engineering for the conversion of NO3 − to NH3 [107]. As evidenced by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, defect engineering via V doping modulated the electronic orbitals of MoS2, lowered the energy barrier of PDS, and improved the NO3 − conversion rate and NH3 selectivity. Incorporation of Co vacancies into Co3O4 nanosheet array altered the local electronic environment around Co sites, enhancing the charges of Co sites, therefore boosting NO3 − adsorption [108]. Additionally, they also observed that the eNO3RR activity of Co3O4 with OVs was better than Co3O4 [109]. Therefore, it is worth to further explore whether the eNO3RR performance of Co3O4 with cation and anion defects can be maximised. Ni nanosheet arrays (Ni-NSA-VNi) containing Ni vacancies generated by H2 plasma treatment exhibited excellent activities towards selective eNO2RR [110]. Surface electron cloud density of Ni-NSA-VNi was lower than that of the Ni foam (Fig. 7e and f). The decrease in surface electron cloud density triggered by Ni vacancies facilitated NO2 − adsorption and activation and NH3 desorption, leading to an FE of 88.9% and a selectivity of 77.2%. Notably, Ni-NSA-VNi can serve as bifunctional electrodes for the simultaneous synthesis of NH3 and dihydroisoquinoline. The works discussed above effectively prove the promoting effect of vacancy defects on eNO x RR. Constructing vacancy defects, especially OVs, is an effective means to tune the electronic structure and surface properties of metal oxides. However, the method for precise control of vacancy defects has not yet been established. The current methods used to construct vacancy defects are prone to give random growth and distribution of defects, making it difficult to control the concentration of defects. The uneven distribution of active sites within catalysts results in poor stability. Thereby, it is urgent to develop technologies that can accurately and quantitatively control the formation of vacancy defects. 4.2 Heteroatom doping In addition to vacancy defect introduction, heteroatom doping is an effective approach for improving electrocatalytic performance. The electronic structure of an electrocatalyst can be modulated by doping the electrocatalyst with heteroatom [111]. Synergistic electron transfer interaction between metal species can change the electronic state of the metal atom centre, thereby optimising the adsorption energies of important reaction intermediates. The doped metal can adjust the electronic band and act as an active site. Zhang et al. prepared nickel phosphide doped with Fe (Fe/Ni2P) for eNO3RR [112]. They performed ultraviolet electron spectroscopy (UPS) to examine electronic interactions between different elements and the chemical states of Fe/Ni2P and Ni2P. The maximum valence bands of Fe/Ni2P and Ni2P were 2.28 and 1.72 eV, respectively, demonstrating that Fe doping downshifted the d-band centre of Ni2P (Fig. 8 a). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results revealed that the electronic structure of the catalyst was altered by the strong interactions between Ni and Fe (Fig. 8b and c), which eventually affected the catalytic activity of Fe/Ni2P. They further used the catalyst to assemble a novel Zn-NO3 − battery, which realised a “three-win” strategy for energy supply, NH3 synthesis, and pollutant removal. Peng et al. chose a popular HER catalyst, Mo2C, and investigated how single-atom Ru dopants in Mo2C modified the reaction kinetics and accelerated eNO3RR [113]. As evidenced by theoretical computations and kinetic isotope measurements, the sink point for adsorbed H was Ru dopants that facilitated the deoxygenations of *NO3 and *NO2. Doping heteroatoms into TM oxides is also an efficient means of optimising intermediate adsorption and triggering defect engineering, thus enhancing the catalytic performance. Guo et al. used an ion-exchange method to produce Pd-doped TiO2 nanorod arrays (Pd/TiO2) for electrocatalytic NO3 − conversion [114]. According to the calculated projected density of states (PDOS), stronger hybridisation between the O atoms of NO3 −and Pd/TiO2 indicated a more favourable eNO3RR over Pd/TiO2 (Fig. 8d). As shown in the three-dimensional (3D) and two-dimensional (2D) electron density difference (EDD) images (Fig. 8e and f), a large extent of electron density depletion was noticed at the Pd site, whereas a small extent of electron density accumulation was observed at the O site as compared with the cases of pristine TiO2. Pd/TiO2 possesses a stronger ability to capture electrons from NO3 − than that of TiO2 because of the presence of Pd. Owing to weakened intermediate adsorption abilities induced by Pd doping (Fig. 8g), the Pd/TiO2 electrocatalyst exhibited an impressive NH3 yield with exceptional FE and NO3 − conversion. Non-noble metal V is widely present in nature and is one of the constituent elements of nitrite reductase. Considering the advantages of V, Sun’s team adopted V as dopants to optimise TiO2 [115]. Due to the enhanced intrinsic conductivity and accelerated PDS, V-doped TiO2 nanobelt arrays successfully transformed NO2 − into NH3 with better R NH3 and FE. As reported by Song et al., OVs can be activated via highly dispersed trace Cu doping into TiO2 nanotube array [116]. Electrochemical characterisation and DFT calculations suggested that Cu doping promoted charge transfer and reduced the energy barrier of PDS. Similarly, Zhang et al. developed TiO2 nanotube with OVs by Co doping [117]. The N2 formation barrier was increased by OVs, and the desorption of *NO/*NO2 was suppressed by the doped Co, thus boosting the NH3 production. Very recently, Wang et al. reported that considerable OVs were triggered and abundant active sites for NO3 − reduction were generated by doping Fe single atoms into TiO2 [118]. The positively charged surfaces of Fe sites prevented HER and facilitated the adsorption and activation of NO3 −, thus achieving high R NH3 and FE. Zhang et al. also employed a single-atom doping strategy to fabricate a single-atom Fe-doped V2O5 (Fe-V2O5) electrocatalyst enriched with Lewis acid sites [119]. They revealed that the significant R NH3 and FE (12.5 mg h−1 cm−2 and 97.1%, respectively) stemmed from the Lewis acid Fe-V pairs to enhance the hydrogenation energetics and alleviate HER. For non-metal doping, S, N, B, O, C, and P atoms are usually selected as heteroatoms to improve the electrocatalytic activities of pristine materials [120]. Introduction of non-metal atoms can not only tune the bandgap of the electrocatalyst, leading to abundant charge density and higher intrinsic conductivity, but also reduce the binding energies of reactants. Wang et al. found that doping an appropriate level of S into Fe foam can tune the electronic structure and *H affinity of catalyst [121]. The activity and durability of S-doped Fe foam (FeS0.2@FF) towards eNO3RR were higher than that of Fe foam. In situ DEMS showed that no *NO2 was produced during eNO3RR process, indicating easier *NO2 conversion. In addition, DFT calculations revealed that modifying Fe with S could modulate interaction between catalysts and N-intermediates. Li et al. loaded Fe single atoms on S and N-codoped carbon (Fe-CNS) to catalyse eNO3RR [65]. S-doping optimised the coordination environment of the metal centres and created numerous defects, leading to higher activity of eNO3RR. Zhang et al. introduced B to Cu nanoparticles to regulate the electronic states of Cu [122]. Notably, the outstanding eNO3RR performance originated from increased Cu+ concentration because of B-doping. Ru/O-doped Ru core/shell nanoclusters were employed in eNO3RR [123]. Tensile lattice strains were attributed to the expansions of Ru unit cells caused by O dopants. By tailoring the subsurface O concentration, the tensile lattice strain was regulated, thereby inhibiting HER and promoting NO3 − reduction. Existence of H• and beneficial effects of H• on eNO3RR kinetics were confirmed by electron spin resonance (ESR) spectroscopy. 5,5-Dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) was used as the H• spin-trapping reagent. When the concentration of KNO3 was increased from 0 to 1 M, the intensity of the DMPO-H-assigned peak gradually attenuated (Fig. 8h), which strongly proved that H• participated in eNO3RR. The significantly reduced eNO3RR partial current densities and increased activation energies revealed the function of H• in reducing the kinetic barriers of hydrogenating intermediates (Fig. 8i). Zhang et al. successfully converted NO2 − to NH3 with an FE of approximately 100% in a wide potential range [124]. As evidenced by theoretical calculations, the upshift of the d-band centres and reduced energy barrier of PDS after C doping were the reasons for the robust catalytic activity of C/Co3O4. Furthermore, a C/Co3O4-based Zn-NO2 − battery was used to simultaneously synthesise NH3 and generate electricity. P can not only accommodate the surface charge state but also induce charge redistribution, owing to its owning vacant 3d orbitals and lone-pair electrons in 3p orbitals. Inspired by this, Sun’s team utilised P as a modifier to regulate the electronic structure of TiO2 [125]. P-doped TiO2 possessed higher conductivity and faster charge transfer rate, which facilitated NO2 −-to-NH3 conversion. Metal/non-metal doping can deform crystals, alter the surface work function of materials, thus optimising the adsorption of intermediates. Dopant can aggregate adsorb *H during eNO x RR process, facilitating the cooperative deoxygenation of intermediates on co-catalytic sites. Therefore, the co-catalytic system can minimise competitive HER to enhance catalytic activity of catalyst. Correspondingly, highly active HER catalysts can be transformed into superior eNO x RR catalysts by heteroatom doping. 4.3 Alloying Alloying is a unique method of tailoring the electronic and geometric structures of electrocatalyst surfaces [126,127]. The ensemble effect of heterogeneous metal species can stabilise intermediates or promote multistep reactions, rendering alloying a suitable choice for eNO x RR. Cu-based alloys have been extensively examined as excellent catalysts for NH3 production. Wang et al. investigated the adsorption energy–activity relationship for a series of Cu–Ni alloys with different Cu:Ni ratios [128]. Under steady-state operating conditions, the Cu50Ni50 catalyst retained pure metal characteristics in both the Ni and Cu K-edge spectra at a series of applied potentials (Fig. 9 a and b). According to UPS (Fig. 9c), an increase in the Ni content in the alloy led to a positive shift of the d-band centre towards Fermi level (E f), which was consistent with the XPS results. This demonstrated reduced antibonding occupation and stronger adsorbate bonding. Therefore, the alloying of Cu and Ni significantly improved the adsorption energies of intermediate products such as *NO3 −, *NO2, and *NH2, and enhanced the electrocatalytic performance. CuNi alloys have also been reported to exhibit outstanding activities towards eNO3RR by Fang et al. [129] and Zhang et al. [130]. In Fang’s work, Cu0.43Ni0.57/NC displayed the best eNO3RR activity among a series of alloys with different Cu:Ni ratios. The enhanced activity was ascribed to the alleviated NO2 − accumulation, optimised *NO2 deoxidation, and porous substrate. Uneven element distribution caused by phase separation of alloys restrains the further optimisation of activity. Zhang et al. provided a reasonable design concept of tracking the phase state of bimetallic alloys to regulate the catalytic activity. Alloying of Cu and Pd has received widespread attention due to the outstanding catalytic abilities of Cu and Pd towards NO3 − reduction [131–133]. Yin et al. stated that PdCu alloys in PdCu/Cu2O hybrids promoted the generation of *N intermediates [134]. Pd species led to the polarisation of Cu 3d and provided empty orbitals for NO3 − adsorption. Based on machine learning and d-band theory, Gao et al. calculated the adsorption energies (Fig. 9d) of *N and *NO3 on the (111) and (100) metal facets to filter the appropriate intermetallic for highly efficient NH3 synthesis from NO3 − [135]. They discovered that the (100)-type sites of ordered B2 intermetallics realised non-scaling behaviours, in which *NO3 adsorption was favoured and *N was destabilised owing to Pauli repulsion interactions, thereby breaking the adsorption–energy scaling relations between *N and *NO3 and accelerating the conversion of N-bonded species to NH3. According to theoretical prediction, they prepared ordered intermetallic B2 CuPd nanocubes (Fig. 9e), which realised high-efficiency NH3 generation with an impressive FE (∼91.8 mg h−1 mg−1 and 92.5% at –0.5 V vs. RHE). Alloying of Cu with other metals has also been investigated [136]. Co have often been chosen for alloying with Cu because of its facile preparation and effective regulation of the property of Cu. For instance, Fang et al. fabricated CuCo alloy nanosheets that mimicked the bifunctional properties of Cu-type NO2 − reductases and easily reduced NO2 − via the cooperation of two catalytic centres [137]. Co served as an electron-/proton-donating centre, whereas Cu boosted NO x − adsorption/association. Among noble metals, Ru exhibits exceptional catalytic performance and has been alloyed with Cu. A Ru-dispersed Cu nanowire (Ru-CuNW) was synthesised for the conversion of NO3 − into NH3 at low NO3 − concentrations [138]. Ru-CuNW demonstrated an industrial-relevant NH3 current with a high FE of 96%. The low NO3 − activation barrier of Ru and HER inhibition ability of Cu led to high eNO3RR performance, as evidenced by DFT calculations. By combining electrolysis in eNO3RR with air stripping, wastewater was transformed into high value-added NH3 products (solid NH4Cl and liquid NH3). In a study of NO3 − reduction using RuCu alloys, Gao et al. discovered that a relay catalysis occurred when Ru and Cu were coupled [139]. Relay catalysis was verified by in situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 9f and g), where Cu was the exclusively effective site for NO3 −–NO2 − catalysis, whereas Ru was the highly active site for NO2 −–NH3 catalysis. DFT calculations revealed that the generation of RuCu alloy modulated the d-band centre, facilitated *NO2 adsorption, and boosted NH3 desorption (Fig. 9h), enabling high performance of eNO3RR. Gao et al. proposed a three-step relay mechanism consisting of a spontaneous redox reaction, electrochemical reduction, and electrocatalytic reduction to improve EE of NO3 − reduction [140]. Using Ru x Coy alloys as electrocatalysts, they achieved an outstanding EE of 42% ± 2% with an FE of 97% ± 5% and an R NH3 of 54.4 ± 2.89 mg h−1 mg−1 at ultralow overpotential. Recently, Zhao et al. constructed an Fe SAC-supported RuFe bimetallic alloy that induced the heteroatom ensemble effect and optimised the adsorption of intermediate for eNO3RR [141]. SAAs with unique electronic structures have attracted considerable attention [142,143]. For example, single-atom Bi alloyed Pd metallene (Bi1Pd) was discovered to be an exceptional eNO3RR catalyst. Bi1-Pd electronic coupling activated NO3 − and destabilised *NO, thereby reducing the energy barrier of PDS and facilitating NO3 − hydrogenation. Note that ordered intermetallic SAAs (ISAAs) have recently been considered to be on behalf of a structural motif with the highest density of isolated atoms. Cu/CuAu core/shell NCs with tuneable ISAA layers controlled the densities of Au SAAs on a Cu surface, triggering ligand effects that optimised the *NO3 and *N chemisorptions, thereby delivering an R NH3 of 11.937 mg h−1 cm−2 and an FE of 94.7% [144]. Recently, Xie et al. developed an ISAA In–Pd bimetallene with Pd atoms isolated in the In host [145]. The eNO3RR catalytic performance (an R NH3 of 28.06 mg h−1 mgPd −1 and an FE of 87.2%) was attributed to the downshifted Pd d-orbitals with significantly narrower energy bands, which narrowed p-d hybridization between In and Pd around E f. Additionally, an alloy of a noble metal and light non-metal was demonstrated to be an active catalyst for eNO3RR. Sun et al. designed a series of mesoporous PdX nanocubes alloyed with six non-metals (that is, H, B, C, N, P, and S) [146]. The best meso-PdN NCs demonstrated significant performances due to promoted NO3 − adsorption, timely NH3 desorption, and increased retention times of key intermediates. Subtle adjustment of the element ratio in alloys is a typical method for achieving excellent catalytic activity. Most research focuses on binary alloys, while investigations on ternary or more multicomponent alloys are rarely reported. It has been reported that high-entropy alloys featuring unique corrosion resistance exhibit excellent catalytic performance in some reactions. Therefore, multicomponent alloys may be a promising eNO x RR catalyst. 4.4 Single-atom catalysis active sites Single-atom catalysts (SACs) comprising isolated metal sites have attracted widespread attention because of approximately 100% atomic utilisation, adjustable coordination environments, and homogenised catalytically active centres [147–150]. Notably, the coupling of two neighbouring N-containing intermediates (*NO or *N) can be avoided because of the isolated metal sites of SACs. Thereby, SACs exhibit considerable potentials for the conversion of NO3 − to NH3. Various single TM atoms have been embedded in diverse substrates, and N-doped C materials are considered as promising supports for single metal atoms by the synthesis of metal-nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) [151]. Via theoretical calculations, Cu, Re, Os, Ti, and Zr SACs have been predicted as promising catalysts for the electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3. Wang et al. explored the reaction mechanisms and performance origins of eNO3RR over TM-N4-doped graphene (TM-N4/C) [152]. Product selectivity was evaluated by constructing the volcano plots of −ΔG ma x , which is typically employed to measure the onset potential. Volcano plots (Fig. 10 a and b) indicated that Cu-N4/C and Pt-N4/C formed NH3 and N2 with the highest selectivity, respectively. As demonstrated by contour plots (Fig. 10c) with ΔG *NO and ΔG *N as descriptors, Re-N4/C was most efficient for NH3 synthesis, whereas Pt-N4/C was most effective for N2 production. In another theoretical insight into SACs for eNO3RR, Wang et al. observed that Os SAC was the most promising electrocatalyst among 23 TM SACs [153]. The outstanding eNO3RR activity of Os SAC originated from pronounced hybridisation between the Os atom and NO3 −. Os and Fe SACs are located near the top of the volcano plot and possess excellent limiting potentials of −0.53 and −0.42 V, respectively. Niu et al. innovatively and comprehensively examined the eNO3RR activity trends of single TMs (from Ti to Au) loaded on graphitic carbon nitrides (TM/g-CN) via first-principles calculations [154]. They concluded that high-efficiency NH3 synthesis with low limiting potentials of −0.41 and −0.39 V could be achieved on Zr/g-CN and Ti/g-CN, respectively. Moreover, the production of by-products (N2, N2O, NO2, and NO) was inhibited by considerable energy barriers, endowing these catalysts with high selectivity. SACs have exhibited excellent performances towards eNO3RR in laboratory experiments. Metal-organic framework (MOF)-assisted pyrolysis and SiO2 template-assisted pyrolysis are typical methods for constructing SACs. For example, Cu SAC (CuNC) prepared by pyrolysing zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) can transform NO3 − into NH3 [155]. Generations of NO2 − and N2 were significantly inhibited by CuNC because NO2 − adsorption was enhanced and N–N coupling was restrained. A single-atom Cu catalyst (CuSANPC) was synthesised via the carbonisation of a Cu-containing ZIF-8 precursor [156]. The CuN4 site endowed CuSANPC with considerable activity towards eNO3RR as compared to the case of the Cu nanoparticle catalyst. In another work, Cu SACs with Cu(I)–N3C1 sites were prepared for efficient NH3 electrosynthesis via NO3 − reduction [157]. *NO3 and *H were adsorbed on neighbouring Cu and C sites with balanced adsorption energies; thus, the site competition between eNO3RR and HER was alleviated, and hydrogenation of intermediates to NH3 was promoted. Atomic Cu sites embedded in nitrogenated C nanosheets (CuNC) also demonstrated outstanding performance in eNO3RR [158]. Higher NO2 − conversion rate and lower NO2 − selectivity were achieved on CuNC, avoiding NO2 − pollution during eNO3RR process. Isolated Cu coordinated with N (specifically Cu-N2) was the key to adsorb NO3 − and NO2 −. Atomic Cu-doped BCN (B-doped CN) fabricated by structural confinement engineering was used to reduce NO3 − to NH3 and exhibited excellent catalytic activity [159]. The presence of Cu determines whether BCN-Cu can catalyse eNO3RR for NH3 synthesis, and the existence of B improves the catalytic performance of BCN-Cu. Getting more insight into the evolution of catalyst is helpful for understanding the mechanism. Xu et al. developed a Cu single-atom precatalyst anchored on an anticollapse MOF and applied it to catalyse NO3 − conversion [160]. An R NH3 of 1.12 mg h−1 cm−2, an FE of 85.5%, and a selectivity of ∼100% were achieved. Single Cu atoms underwent in situ reconstruction into uniform ultrasmall nanoclusters (approximately 4 nm) during eNO3RR, which was confirmed by in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). Notably, the confined space afforded by the anticollapse MOF prevented excessive aggregation of Cu atoms. Theoretical calculations suggested that the facilitated NO3 − activation and decreased energy barrier stemmed from the size effect and host–guest interaction. By coupling operando XAS and advanced electron microscopy, Yang et al. revealed the evolution mechanism of the as-synthesised Cu-N4 single-atom site to Cu0 nanoparticles during eNO3RR [161]. The HAADF-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image obtained before electrolysis demonstrated single-atom nature of CuNC, whereas the HAADF-STEM image acquired after electrolysis exhibited Cu nanoparticles with 5–10 nm sizes (Fig. 10d and e), indicating the aggregation of Cu sites. After electrolysis, the aggregated Cu nanoparticles restored to Cu-N4 upon exposure to the environmental atmosphere. Operando XAS experiments also verified that the Cu-N4 structure successively transformed into Cu-N3, near-free Cu0 single atoms, and ultimately to aggregated Cu0 nanoparticles, driven by the applied potential. Thereby, an evolution mechanism (Fig. 10f) for potential-driven restructuring and oxidation-driven redispersion was proposed. Simultaneous changes in FE and Cu0 percentage with respect to the applied potential implied that Cu0 nanoparticles were the real active sites instead of Cu-N4. Fe SACs have also demonstrated catalytic activities for the NH3 electrosynthesis from NO3 −. Using a polymer-hydrogel strategy, Li et al. constructed Fe SACs with even atomic dispersions [162]. A maximum R NH3 of 2.75 mg h−1 cm−2 was achieved at –0.7 V vs. RHE. Preoccupation of NO3 − on Fe(II)-N x was confirmed to inhibit water adsorption as the competing reaction. Wu et al. developed another Fe SAC comprising an Fe-N4 structure via SiO2 template-assisted carbonisation [163]. N–N coupling for N2 formation was significantly prevented by the lack of neighbouring metal sites, which promoted NH3 selectivity. In another study, harmful algal biomass was recycled as a functional atomically dispersed Fe catalyst for eNO3RR [164]. DFT calculations revealed that the Fe-N4 sites reduced the energy barriers and enhanced the electrocatalytic activity. Zhang et al. reported an Fe SAC with a unique FeN2O2 coordination structure, which exhibited high conductivity and activity when compared with those of the FeN4 structure [165]. Most recently, a series of Fe/NC SACs were constructed via pyrolysis at 800–1000 °C (Fe1/NC-X) [166]. Fe1/NC-900 possessed dominant active sites of Fe-N3 (trigonal pyramidal), which demonstrated more lone pair electrons and stronger ability to adsorb NO3 −, thus exhibiting high activity. Integrating bimetallic sites to construct a dual SAC can optimise the activity of SAC with the following reasons: (1) the electronic state of pristine metal is altered after introducing another metal. (2) the distinct reaction pathways can be synergized over bimetallic sites. Murphy et al. prepared a series of Fe- and Mo-based SACs that reduced NO3 − to NH3 via distinct and synergised NO2 − pathways [167]. The single FeMo bimetallic catalyst synergised the two reaction mechanisms on FeNC and MoNC, thus achieving high performance. Other metallic SACs, such as Ru, Rh, and Ag SACs, have also been investigated as electrocatalysts for NO3 −/NO2 − reduction. Yao et al. reported a novel inherent oxide anchoring strategy that fixed isolated Ru atoms on a monolithic Ti substrate by tuning the electronic metal–support interactions (Fig. 10g) [168]. Fourier transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectrum verified the single-atom nature of Ru (Fig. 10h). The monolithic single-atom electrode demonstrated outstanding electrocatalytic chlorine evolution and eNO3RR activities. Ke et al. also successfully converted NO x − into NH3 on isolated Ru sites, with maximal FEs of 72.8% (NO3 − reduction) and 97.8% (NO2 − reduction) [169]. Liu et al. explored different electrocatalysts based on Rh clusters and single atoms supported on Cu nanowires (Rh@Cu) for NO3 − electrocatalysis [170]. The excellent NH3 yield and FE were attributed to effective cooperation between Ru and Cu, in which Ru supplied the adsorbed *H required for the surface hydrogenation of *NO on Cu. Recently, Ag SACs with N, O trans coordination were applied to catalyse NO3 − to NH3 [171]. Trans-AgN2O2 configuration inhibited HER, optimised intermediate adsorption, and facilitated RDS in eNO3RR. SACs possess higher density of active sites compared with bulk materials. Nevertheless, the stability of SACs attracted less attentions. Single atoms are prone to aggregate or migrate during eNO x RR process owing to low coordination and high surface energy. Single atoms need to be anchored on substrate and the type of substrate affects the performance of SACs. Choosing a suitable substrate is an effective method for regulating the coordination environment and improving stability of SACs. 4.5 Heterostructures Designing catalysts with heterostructures is an important strategy to achieve high activities. Heterostructures are usually composed of building blocks with different surface electronic environments and work functions. Most heterostructure catalysts contain heterojunctions formed via the Mott–Schottky contact. Owing to the Schottky barrier, the energy band at the heterojunction distorts, and electrons spontaneously transfer at the interface until the work function reaches equilibrium. Hence, the electrochemical properties of material are altered by the redistribution of electronic structure at the interface. Adsorption energies of intermediates can be effectively balanced by the electronic effect of the heterojunction, thus improving the reaction kinetics [172]. CuCl (111) and rutile TiO2 (110) layers were stacked together to create an electrocatalyst (CuCl_BEF) for electrochemical NO3 − reduction [173]. The nanoshuttles were primarily composed of rutile TiO2, as indicated by its characteristic (101) and (110) lattice fringes (Fig. 11 a and b). Additionally, the diffraction fringes of CuCl (220) and CuCl (111) were noticed on the CuCl nanodots in each nanoshuttle. X-ray diffraction patterns also confirmed the existences of TiO2 and CuCl (Fig. 11c). A built-in electric field was triggered by electron transfer from TiO2 to CuCl, which substantially accumulated higher NO3 − concentration near the electrocatalyst surface. Consequently, mass transfer for efficient eNO3RR at ultralow NO3 − concentration was accelerated. Moreover, the electric field increased the energy of the key reaction intermediate *NO, thereby lowering the energy barrier of RDS. Similarly, the built-in electric fields established in the heterojunctions of CuO/MnO2 [174] and CoP/TiO2 [175] also boosted the conversion of NO3 − into NH3. Additionally, porous-rich Pd/CuO nano-olives were confirmed to be efficient catalyst for eNO2RR [176]. Construction of a heterojunction between Cu3P and TiO2 increased the overall electrical conductivity, leading to rapid charge transfer in NO2 − reduction [177]. Li et al. synthesised surface B-rich core–shell Ni boride catalysts (called Ni3B@NiB2.74) for electrochemical NO x − reduction [178]. Ex situ characterisations coupled with in situ spectrometric measurements revealed a dual-site reaction mechanism, where the Ni sites decomposed water to provide protons and the B sites accelerated NO x − adsorption and suppressed HER and surface Ni oxidation. Zhang et al. constructed MOF-derived Co-doped Fe@Fe2O3 (Co-Fe@Fe2O3) to catalyse eNO3RR [179]. Mechanical calculation verified that Co doping tuned the Fe d-band centre, thus modulating the intermediate adsorption energy and inhibiting HER. He et al. proposed a concept for designing tandem catalysts, which involved combining potential-dependent intermediate phases of diverse TMs to serve as synergistic electrocatalytic sites for cascade NO3 − conversion [180]. FE and R NH3 were 90.6% and 19.891 mg h−1 cm−2 at −0.175 V vs. RHE, respectively. They used ex situ XPS and Raman spectroscopy to identify the surface phase compositions (Fig. 11d and e) and in situ Raman spectroscopy to monitor the phase evolutions of electrocatalysts (Fig. 11f). In this tandem catalysis system, NO2 − generated on the inner Cu/CuO x phases was rapidly hydrogenated to NH3 at the nearby Co/CoO shell at low overpotentials. A Ru/β-Co(OH)2 heterostructure electrocatalyst was recently proposed to weaken the ability of d-p orbital hybridisation with *NH3, which thereby reduced the barrier of PDS [181]. Outstanding NO3 −-to-NH3 production performance (39.1 mg h−1 cm−2 and 98.78%) was obtained at 0.01 V vs. RHE. In addition to the original nanosheet-like structure, orderly stacked nanosheets were present (Fig. 11g). A series of physical characterisations (Fig. 11h and i) further suggested that the Ru-doped Co metal nanosheets were in situ reconstructed into a hexagonal Ru/Co(OH)2 heterostructure. Ren et al. in situ-restructured multi-phase heterostructures (Cu/Pd/CuO x ) using a Pd-incorporated Cu-MOF precatalyst [182]. Uneven spatial charge distribution was induced by the heterogeneous interface between Cu, Pd, and CuO x , which strengthened interfacial charge polarisation and promoted NO3 − adsorption. From the perspectives of kinetics and thermodynamics, the most effective methods for improving electrocatalytic activity are accelerating electron transfer, accumulating ion concentration near active sites, and enriching active sites [183]. The built-in electric field formed by heterojunction can promote electron transfer, increase ion concentration near the active site, regulate the reaction microenvironment, and optimise intermediate adsorption/desorption to accelerate multielectron eNO x RR. 4.6 Composites In addition to promoting the intrinsic activities of catalysts, constructing composites is an efficient strategy for enhancing the electrocatalytic performances. Fabrication of composites using two or more materials with different properties can not only combine the advantages of each component but also exert a synergistic effect between the components via an appropriate composite structure. Composites of metals and their compounds with carbon or non-carbon materials are comprehensively discussed hereinafter. Combining metals and their compounds with conductive carbon materials can improve the overall catalytic performances of metals and their compounds. Xu et al. synthesised NH3 via NO3 − reduction using Co nanoparticle-decorated N-doped carbon composites (MR Co-NC) [184]. Owing to the combined advantages of the large specific surface area of the carbon framework and high intrinsic activity of metallic Co, MR Co-NC exhibited excellent activity towards eNO3RR. The exclusive 3D mesoporous carbon framework of the catalyst facilitated long-range charge and mass transport and prevented the reconstruction of active sites. Wang et al. utilised biomass juncus-derived carbon decorated with Co nanoparticles (Co@JDC) to achieve electrocatalytic NO2 − conversion [185]. DFT calculations suggested that the lower d-band centres and less positive charges of the Co atoms reduced the intermediate adsorption energies, thus enhancing the catalytic activity and selectivity of Co@JDC towards eNO2RR. Moreover, Co@JDC demonstrated significant catalytic activity for NO3 −-to-NH3 production. The same group fabricated another composite, namely, Cu nanoparticle-decorated juncus-derived C (Cu/JDC), to catalyse eNO2RR [186]. A high FE of 93.2% and a superior R NH3 of 8.9 mg h−1 mg−1 were obtained on Cu/JDC in alkaline solution. Composites of TM phosphides with H-adsorbing abilities have been reported to exhibit outstanding activities in both NO3 − and NO2 − reductions. For instance, CoP nanosheet arrays grown on carbon fibre cloth (CoP NAs/CFC) demonstrated considerable activities towards eNO3RR, delivering an R NH3 of 16.25 mg h−1 cm−2 with an FE of ∼100% [187]. The excellent performance of CoP NAs/CFC originated from the stabilisation of the active phase and optimisation of the energy barriers by P. Additionally, operando XAS proved that the Co 4p orbitals directly participated in the NO3 − adsorption and electron transfer. eNO3RR and benzyl alcohol oxidation were combined to realise the syntheses of high value-added chemicals at the cathode and anode. Similarly, a hollow CoP nanosphere catalyst anchored on a self-supported carbon nanosheet array was used to achieve the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − [188]. In situ experiments (Fig. 12 a and b) coupled with DFT calculations (Fig. 12c) indicated that the dynamic equilibrium between the generation and timely consumption of H(ad) gave rise to an outstanding R NH3 of 143.99 mg h−1 cm−2 with an FE of 88.6%. In addition to composites of metals and their compounds with carbon materials, composites of compounds and metals can be used to realise optimal electrochemical performance. For example, Cu3P nanowire arrays loaded on Cu foam (Cu3P NA/CF), CoP nanoarrays anchored on a Ti mesh (CoP NA/TM), and Ni2P nanosheet arrays on Ni foam (Ni2P/NF) exhibited good catalytic activities towards eNO2RR [189–191]. Furthermore, Yuan et al. achieved the conversion of NO2 − to NH3 on an FeP composite (FeP NA|Ti) [192]. They observed that both the reaction rate and selectivity were substantially affected by atomic H (*H). A Pd-metallene-supported sub-nm RuO x cluster (RuO x /Pd) was demonstrated to be an effective eNO3RR electrocatalyst (Fig. 12d) [193]. At −0.5 V vs. RHE, NH3 was formed with an FE of 98.6% and an R NH3 of 23.5 mg h−1 cm−2. Operando spectroscopic measurements combined with mechanical calculations elucidated the synergistic role of RuO x and Pd in enhancing the eNO3RR activity of the catalyst via a mechanism of hydrogen spillover and hydrogen-bonding interactions (Fig. 12e). Most current study is conducted in alkaline/neutral electrolyte, while eNO3RR in acidic electrolyte is rarely investigated. Recently, Zhang et al. hybridised TiO2 nanosheet with iron phthalocyanine (FePc) and used this composite (FePc/TiO2) for eNO3RR under acidic conditions [194]. Initially, they studied the electrochemical performance of TiO2 at different pHs. They found that TiO2 demonstrated the potential for rapid NH3 synthesis from NO3 − under acidic media. However, TiO2 only achieved an FE of 78.5% under acidic condition, which is unsatisfactory. For further improvement, FePc with promising eNO3RR activity was selected to hybridise with TiO2. Due to the enhanced NO3 − adsorption, suppressed HER, and reduced energy barrier, the resulting catalyst delivered a significant improvement in NH3 formation. Then, an alkaline-acid hybrid Zn–NO3 − battery realising a high open circuit potential (1.99 V) and power density (91.4 mW cm−2) was developed. Furthermore, a N2H4-NO3 − fuel cell could be applied for simultaneous N2H4/NO3 − elimination and electricity supply. Potential-induced self-reconstruction is a common phenomenon in electrochemical reactions. The material undergoes a phase transition at the operating potential, producing new active phases. Therefore, potential-induced self-reconstruction can serve as an effective strategy for synthesising composites with better catalytic properties. In recent years, Cu-based composites prepared by self-reconstruction have been extensively investigated. Some studies have reported that Cu transitions from high to low valence states, forming composites. For example, a Cu-Al2O3 interface with strong metal–support interactions (CuAl-LDO-r) was constructed via in situ electroreduction of a CuAl-mixed oxide [195]. The CuOAl bonds at the CuAl2O3 interface led to the generation and stabilisation of electron-deficient Cu δ+. In situ spectrometric measurements combined with mechanistic investigations demonstrated that strong affinity of Cuδ+ towards N-intermediates accounted for high activity and selectivity of CuAl-LDO-r. Based on ex situ experiments and in situ Raman spectroscopy, Wang et al. revealed that Cu/Cu2O nanowire arrays (Cu/Cu2O NWAs) electrochemically obtained from CuO NWAs served as active species for eNO3RR [196]. As evidenced by DEMS and theoretical calculations, the electron transfer from Cu2O to Cu was beneficial for *NOH generation and impeded HER, contributing to high selectivity and FE. Li et al. reported a NiCu-OH nanocomposite precatalyst that could be reconstructed into eNO3RR and glycerol oxidation electrocatalysts under the operating conditions [197]. The maximum R NH3 of 23.8 mg h−1 cm−2 was acquired at −0.1 V vs. RHE. In contrast, an opposite phenomenon was noticed in other studies, in which Cu2O/Cu composites were reconstructed from Cu. For instance, in situ-reconstructed Cu2O/Cu with rich Cu active sites and electron-rich Cu2O sites was demonstrated as a highly active catalyst for NO3 − reduction [198]. Ultrafast conversion of *NO2 to *NO and highly selective transformation of *NO to *NOH played important roles in eNO3RR by accelerating mass transfer and offering adequate *H. Wang et al. developed an island-like Cu electrocatalyst by in situ electrochemical reduction of metallic Cu [199]. The reduction of Cu to Cu2O was successfully monitored by operando Raman spectroscopy. Mechanistic studies confirmed that the generation of Cu2O active sites in Cu accelerated the production of *HNHOH from *HNOH, facilitating electrocatalytic NO3 − conversion. Very recently, Bu et al. proposed a pulsed electrolysis strategy to realise in situ electrochemical peroxidation and self-repair of the Cu/Cu2O structure, where Cu was converted to CuO during the oxidation pulse and active Cu/Cu2O was revived after reduction [200]. Alloying with Ni further regulated H adsorption, which transferred from Ni/Ni(OH)2 to the N-containing intermediate products on Cu/Cu2O, giving rise to superior eNO3RR performance towards NH3 synthesis. Other TM-based materials have also been demonstrated to undergo self-reconstruction. McEnaney et al. employed a Ti cathode to fabricate NH3 from NO3 − [201]. They observed that high H+ and NO3 − concentrations were required to achieve high selectivity. Furthermore, they noticed the formation of Ti hydride on the Ti cathode surface after electrochemical testing. Nevertheless, whether the real active species in their system was Ti, Ti hydride, or a combination of these species remained unclear. Liu et al. systematically investigated the relationship between near-surface structures of Ti electrodes and eNO3RR performance [202]. Ex situ grazing-incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXRD) coupled with XAS revealed that the enrichment of near-surface TiH2 could be electrochemically adjusted by controlling the eNO3RR applied potential and duration (Fig. 12f–i). This quantitative relationship afforded information about the electrochemical treatment of Ti for the construction of TiH2/Ti electrodes for application in eNO3RR. Constructing composites can not only combine the advantages of different materials, but also modify the materials. The components with different properties can offer synergistic effects for eNO x RR which contains multistep reactions, thereby boosting the eNO x RR performance. Electrochemical self-reconstruction can be used to obtain eNO x RR catalysts, and may occur during eNO x RR processes. In order to confirm the true active sites, it is necessary to pay attention to whether the chemical composition and structure of the catalyst change after eNO x RR. 4.7 Molecular catalysts Owing to well-defined structures, molecular catalysts are capable of facilitating precise control of the steric and electronic properties near the active site. Moreover, by immobilising or tethering molecular catalysts to electrode surfaces, the reaction pathways may be regulated to acquire desired products. Biomimetic enzyme catalysts inspired by NO x − reductase in vivo are typical molecular catalysts that have been widely examined. The direct method for simulating NO x − reductase is constructing similar active structure with NO x − reductase. A Cu-incorporated 3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (Cu-PTCDA) molecular solid catalyst was reported to possess high-efficiency NH3 synthesis capability [203]. The outstanding performance originated from the PTCDA structure facilitating proton/electron transfer, and the unique electronic structure of Cu inhibiting HER. As shown in the EDD of NO3 − on 1Cu–PTCDA ( 1 ¯ 03), a large electron cloud existed between NO3 − and Cu, indicating a strong interaction between NO3 − and Cu (Fig. 13 a). The hybridisation between Cu and O atoms of NO3 − was strong (Fig. 13b). The larger H2 formation energy on Cu–PTCDA ( 1 ¯ 03) than that on Cu (111) suggested that O-Cu–PTCDA impeded HER and accelerated the selective conversion of NO3 − to NH3 (Fig. 13c). Li et al. synthesised an enzyme mimetic intermediate containing a MoV(=O)S4 species for the first time for NO3 − reduction at neutral pH [204]. According to the potentiometric titration analysis, the redox synergy among MoV@S, S radicals, and MoV(=O)S4 may play an important role in the stabilisation of MoV(=O)S4, exhibiting the significance of secondary interactions in boosting eNO3RR. Guo et al. developed a cobalt-tripeptide complex (CoGGH) that catalysed the selective reduction of NO2 − to NH3 and served as a functional mimic of NO2 − reductase enzymes [205]. Arikawa et al. proposed a three-step NO2 − reduction cycle on a dinuclear Ru complex for NH3 synthesis [206]. More recently, bioinspired cobaloximes were used to realise the electrocatalytic reduction of NO2 −, which achieved an FE of 98.5% under close to neutral conditions [207]. Mechanical calculations indicated that the cobaloximes effectively bound to NO2 − and N-containing intermediates, along with successive and rapid electron/proton transfer. After immobilising cobaloximes onto multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), a high NH4 + yield and FE were obtained. The cobaloxime eNO2RR platform coupled with plasma-driven N2 oxidation facilitated preparative-scale generation of NH3 in the form of NH4Cl. Phthalocyanines have the advantages of inexpensive, easy availability, and good chemical stability. Phthalocyanine-based organometallic compounds have been demonstrated to be effective homogeneous catalysts for both eNO3RR and eNO2RR. Initially, phthalocyanine compounds of Zn, Cu, Ni, Co, Fe, and Mn (ZnPc, CuPc, NiPc, CoPc, FePc, and MnPc, respectively) were immobilised on glassy carbon electrodes to reduce NO3 − and NO2 − in alkaline solution [208]. The main product was NH3, and the order of the overpotentials was as follows: glassy carbon electrode < ZnPc < MnPc < CoPc < NiPc < FePc < CuPc. Lu et al. dispersed and anchored CuPc on Ti3C2Tx MXenes to develop the molecular catalyst CuPc@MXene [209]. The combination of DEMS and mechanistic investigations revealed that CuPc molecules inhibited HER and directly reduced NO3 − to NH3 via the ONH reaction pathway. Very recently, Jiang et al. fabricated molecularly dispersed electrocatalysts (MDEs) of CoPc and CuPc on CNTs to catalyse eNO3RR and eNO2RR [210]. MDEs exhibited substantially higher activity and selectivity for NH3 synthesis than those of aggregated molecules. The well-defined active centres in MDEs also helped understand the mechanism and promote performance optimisation via reasonable structural design. CoPc MDE was more active in catalysing eNO2RR as compared to the case of eNO3RR, delivering a jNH3 of 466 mA cm−2 with a corresponding FE of exceed 97% at −0.192 V vs. RHE towards eNO2RR. Numerous strategies, including weak physisorption/electrostatic interactions, electropolymerisation, grafting, and covalent bonding, for immobilising organometallic compounds onto support materials have been proposed; however, these strategies usually result in inadequate coupling between the affixed species and support materials. Fukushima et al. established a new strategy in which molecular catalysts were immobilised on a graphitic electrode via conjugated aromatic pyrazine linkages [211]. Ghosh et al. constructed a graphite-conjugated electrocatalyst (GCC-CoDIM) using this strategy where a diamine macrocycle was assembled at the o-quinone edge defects on a graphite electrode [212]. GCC-CoDIM reduced NO2 − to NH3 with an FE of > 99% at a fast rate. Preliminary mechanistic studies revealed that a change in the mechanism induced by electrode conjugation led to an increase in the reduction rate. The same group further described the synthesis of NH3 using an Fe-based graphite-conjugated catalyst [213]. Theoretical investigations suggested that high-spin (S = 5/2) Fe(III) ions in an FeN4Cl2 coordination environment decorated the graphite electrode surface. Mechanistic investigations, such as in situ XAS, indicated that the key intermediate in eNO3RR was an iron nitrosyl. Electrocatalytic activity can be effectively improved by modifying the surfaces of heterogeneous electrocatalysts with polymers. Polyallylamine (PA)-functionalised frame-like concave RhCu bimetallic nanocubes (PA-RhCu cNCs) have been demonstrated as highly active catalysts for NH3 production from NO3 − [214]. The PA molecules served as functional molecules and shape-directing agents, which led to the synthesis of PA-RhCu cNCs. Theoretical and experimental investigations implied that PA and Cu coregulated the electronic structure and adsorption capacity of Rh. Moreover, the accelerated interfacial mass transfer triggered by PA further affected the intrinsic activity and selectivity of PA-RhCu cNCs. Xu et al. proposed a post-modification method to manufacture polyaniline (PANI)-modified CuO nanowire arrays for the reduction of NO3 − to NH3 [215]. PANI modulated the surface chemical microenvironment of CuO and promoted NO3 − enrichment and hydrogenated species on catalytic surface, thus facilitating the electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3. Nafion is commonly used to mix with catalysts to promote proton transfer or serve as a proton exchange membrane. Different from these application, Mondol et al. fabricated Nafion-modified metal catalysts for the production of NH3 from NO3 − [216]. Experimental results and theoretical investigations indicated that the NO bound of a key Cu-NO intermediate was activated by the Nafion overlayer, thereby accelerating NH3 synthesis. Very recently, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (ILBMB)-modified chloroperoxidase (CPO) was anchored onto polyethyleneimine (PEI)-modified MWCNTs to construct a CPO-ILBMB/MWCNT-PEI bioconjugate [217]. NO2 − was successfully converted to NH3 via electroenzymatic cascade reduction on the bioconjugate (Fig. 13d), and a high FE (96.4%) and R NH3 (112.7 mg h−1 mgCPO −1) were achieved at −0.76 V vs. RHE. FeII species was the key active site for eNO2RR. The dual function of the amino group derived from MWCNT-PEI as a NO2 − enrichment agent and bridge to covalently fix CPO was a significant factor for eNO2RR. Metal-free catalysts have received enormous attention due to their environmentally friendly characteristics [218]. Additionally, metal-free catalysts do not undergo acid leaching, indicating their potential long-term stability in continuous eNO x RR processes. Harmon et al. investigated various MWCNTs for electrocatalytic NO3 − conversion [219]. They discovered that rather than metal impurities, the native carbon surface was responsible for the notable performances of MWCNTs. Notably, heteroatom doping reduced the electrocatalytic performances of MWCNTs, which was contrary to the popular notion [220,221]. Cheng et al. fabricated amorphous graphene (sm-LIG) with a topological structure via facile laser irradiation [222]. The sm-LIG catalyst exhibited a maximum R NH3 of 2.46 mg h−1 cm−2 and an FE of 83.7% at −0.94 V vs. RHE. X-ray pair distribution functions and EPR revealed elongated C–C bonds and abundant unpaired electrons, which demonstrated more suitable adsorption of NO3 −. A series of C-based aerogel electrocatalysts with regulated N species have been used to catalyse eNO3RR [223]. The enhanced NO3 −-to-NH3 production performance stemmed from the strong adsorption of NO3 − on the graphitic-N moiety. Cyclodextrins (CDs) -based nanoreactors were utilised to convert NO3 − into NH3 [224]. The distinct torus-shaped cyclic conformation and uncoordinated edge hydroxyl groups of CDs played critical roles in eNO3RR. Furthermore, experiments indicated that γ-CD-K+ considerably enriched NO3 − via H-bonding and electrostatic interactions and stimulated mass transfer. MOFs and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) featuring porous structures, high surface areas, high-density monodispersed catalytic sites, and periodic metal arrangements have attracted the attention of researchers because of their electrocatalytic performances [225–229]. Yang et al. used first-principles methods to comprehensively evaluate the effects of the span-new multifunction MOF catalysts TM-BHS and TM-BHT in NO3 − degradation [230]. They observed that Zr-BHS exhibited the best performance in eNO3RR. A new electronic descriptor φ is proposed to elucidate why early TM elements demonstrated outstanding electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction performances. Lv et al. synthesised a series of Fe-based trinuclear cluster MOFs to catalyse eNO3RR for NH3 production in a strongly acidic environment [231]. The Fe2Co-MOF realised an R NH3 of 3.46 mg h−1 mg−1 with an NH3 selectivity of 98.5% and an FE of 90.55%. The dinitrogen ligand and metal active site of the catalyst exhibited superior electron/proton conduction capabilities, which contributed to the significant performance of the catalyst. Cu/Co bimetallic conductive MOFs were investigated for eNO3RR [232]. Lv et al. achieved NH3 synthesis from a 2D nickel porphyrin-based COF (NiPr-TPA-COF) (Fig. 13e and f) [233]. NiPr moieties stably adsorbed NO3 − and facilitated electron transfer. Consequently, NiPr-TPA-COF demonstrated an R NH3 2.5 mg h−1 cm−2 with an FE of approximately 85% at –0.8 V vs. RHE. Molecular catalysts feature precisely designed structures, tuneable steric, and well-defined active sites, which makes it possible to solve the structure–function relationship through mechanism research. However, the structure–function relationship of molecular catalysts is not yet clear, and further understanding will favour the development of better eNO x RR catalysts. Demetalization, leaching, and aggregation decrease the stability of molecular catalysts and need to be avoided. Furthermore, improving conductivity is necessary for molecular catalysts to function effectively. 5 Conclusions and outlook As a promising alternative for the traditional Haber-Bosh technology, eNO x RR have attracted plenty of researchers to jointly push this emerging research field forward (Table 1 ). Note that there is still considerable scope for improvement in the performance of the eNO x RR system, and several challenges exist in the practical application of this system. In this review, we have outlined the catalytic mechanism, measurement system, and evaluation criteria for eNO x RR and summarised the research progress in the design of eNO x RR catalysts using several strategies. We propose the following viewpoints and possible solutions to the current challenges in the electrocatalytic reduction of NO x − to NH3: (1) Investigating the performances of catalysts in practical water bodies is necessary. Current researches are mostly conducted under specific conditions using a simple electrolyte composition with little consideration of other factors. Nevertheless, actual water bodies are complex, where organic compounds and other inorganic salts may affect the catalysts. Furthermore, the NO x − concentration range in real water bodies is wide, spanning from hundreds to thousands of ppm. Therefore, the influences of other factors should be comprehensively analysed. Electrochemical tests should be performed within a wide NO x − concentration range to determine whether the electrocatalyst can be used for different water bodies. Electrocatalysts also need to exhibit high activities in wide ranges of pH and potentials. Therefore, low-cost catalysts should be designed on an industrial scale. Realising innovative achievements for practical applications is a challenging issue. (2) Design of a more thermodynamically favourable anode reaction with high value-added products has the potential to realise energy-saving production. The cathode reaction for eNO3RR is often OER, and OER results in low EE because of its high electrodynamic potential (E θ = 1.23 V vs. RHE). A direct solution is to manufacture efficient OER catalysts. Seeking anodic reactions with more thermodynamically favourable processes and high value-added products is more economically valuable, which can not only significantly reduce the overpotential to generate NH3 but also facilitate the collaborative production of anodic value-added products. Research in this direction is still in its infancy, and the detailed reaction mechanism requires further exploration. (3) Application of external light-assisted electrocatalysis is expected to improve the energy efficiency of eNO x RR. At present, the energy efficiency of converting NO x − into NH3 is relatively low. On the one hand, energy consumption can be reduced by optimising the electrocatalytic system, such as optimising the catalyst, adjusting the electrolyte, and designing flowing cell. On the other hand, external forces, including external light, can be utilised. Although photoelectrocatalysis combines the advantages of photocatalysis and electrocatalysis, the solar-to-energy conversion efficiency and R NH3 still need to be improved. (4) Future research should pay attention to realising the reversible cycling of Zn-NO x − cell and clarify whether such devices demonstrate real commercial values. Zn-NO x − batteries comprising Zn plates with low electromotive forces as anodes simultaneously achieve NO x − removal, NH3 synthesis, and energy supply. However, most of the reported Zn-NO x − batteries are primary cells, which can only be discharged via the consumption of Zn and cannot be charged via NH3 oxidation. Although researchers have reported that Zn-NO x − batteries are theoretically and experimentally rechargeable, it is difficult for the Zn plate to return to its original state. When a Zn-NO x − battery is employed as a disposable battery, different gases, for example, CO2/CO, with co-catalytic functions can be added for coupling reactions. (5) Using NO2 −/NO3 − as N sources and coupling them with other processes, high-efficiency C-N coupling can be achieved for the synthesis of high value-added chemicals, particularly urea. Current reaction systems are still in their early stages, and an in-depth understanding of the mechanism needs to be obtained. A profound understanding of the reaction mechanism helps promote the optimisation of catalysts and catalytic systems, thereby facilitating efficient catalytic processes and practical applications. (6) Proposing uniform criteria for evaluating the performances of catalysts is important. The performances (such as R NH3, FE, selectivity, and conversion rate) of different catalysts need to be examined and compared under the same conditions including the same initial NO x − concentration, type and concentration of electrolyte, potential, and reaction time. (7) DFT calculations should be combined with experiments to systematically investigate the mechanism and reaction pathway of eNO x RR. Explaining the reaction mechanism only via DFT calculations without experimental verification is insufficient. Operando characterisation and isotope labelling methods are crucial tools for clarifying the reaction intermediates and mechanisms. Intermediates determined by operando characterisation should be considered while analysing reaction pathways. (8) Electrochemical self-reconstruction must be considered during eNO x RR. Self-reconstruction may occur during eNO x RR; thus, investigating whether the chemical compositions and structures of catalysts change before and after the reaction is necessary. Identifying the actual active sites is of significant importance. In situ characterisation should be applied to monitor the evolutions of catalysts to gain a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanism. (9) It is necessary to develop catalysts that can maintain high activity after long-term electrolysis. The catalyst structure and electrolyte conditions are two main factors that may affect the long-term stability of the catalyst. There is still lack of profound understanding on how catalyst structure and electrolyte conditions affect the long-term stability. Therefore, it is important to understand the relationship between long-term stability and catalyst structure. The study of the stability will benefit from advanced characterisations and theoretical calculations. (10) Mechanisms of the effects of pH and water splitting on eNO x RR should be further explored. eNO x RR is a multi-electron and multi-proton transfer process that is considerably affected by solution pH and active H. Catalysts usually possess higher R NH3 and FE values and lower overpotentials in alkaline electrolytes. Nevertheless, the underlying mechanism is not yet clear and the experimental evidence is scarce. Because of the consumption of protons during NH3 production, pH of the neutral electrolyte continuously increases, which may alter the reaction pathway. Ignoring the change in pH may mislead the analysis of the reaction mechanism. Water splitting provides active H for the protonation of intermediates to NH3 in alkaline and neutral electrolytes. A balance between the supply and consumption of *H should be maintained to avoid a decrease in R NH3 and the generation of H2. Generally, the electrochemical conversion of NO x − offers an attractive alternative to purify wastewater and produce NH3 in a sustainable way. On the one hand, the catalytic mechanism should be comprehensively understood via experimental investigations, advanced characterisations, and theoretical calculations to guide the rational design of efficient catalysts. On the other hand, considering that the current researches are still in the laboratory testing stage, catalyst with industrial-grade current density, high FE, and appreciable EE should be explored to meet the needs of industrialisation. We believe that with increase of research resources, optimisation of catalytic systems, and in-depth understanding of reaction mechanisms, the disadvantages of the existing systems can be addressed to achieve energy-saving and environmentally friendly large-scale synthesis of NH3. Since then, she has studied as a graduate student under the tutelage of Prof. Chenglin Yan in the College of Energy at Soochow University. Her current research focus on the electrocatalytic nitrate/nitrite reduction under ambient conditions. Yuzhuo Jiang received his master's degree from Nantong University in 2023. His current research focuses on the design and fabrication of electrocatalysts based on theoretical calculations and experimental research, as well as their applications in electrocatalytic nitrogen cycle and direct ammonia fuel cell. Mengfan Wang is a postdoc fellow in the College of Energy at Soochow University in Suzhou, China. He received his PhD degree from Soochow University in 2021. His current research focuses on rational design of electrocatalytic systems toward gas‐involved electrochemical reactions. Yunfei Huan received his bachelor's degree from Nantong University in 2020, and now is pursuing a master's degree at Nantong University. His current research focuses on electrochemical synthesis of ammonia and electrochemical ammonia oxidation. Qiyang Cheng received his master's degree from Soochow University in 2023, and now is pursuing a doctor's degree at Soochow University in Prof. Chenglin Yan's group. His current research focuses on sustainable production of high value-added chemicals from carbon dioxide and nitrogenous small molecules. Yanzheng He received his bachelor's degree from Soochow University in 2020, and now is pursuing a doctor's degree in the College of Energy at Soochow University in Prof. Chenglin Yan's group. His current research focuses on sustainable production of high value‐added chemicals from carbon dioxide and nitrogenous small molecules. Tao Qian received his PhD degree from Nanjing University in 2014. During 2015–2020, he was an associate professor in the College of Energy at Soochow University. Since May 2021, he became a full professor in the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Nantong University. His research interests focus on the functional materials in energy storage and conversion systems. Chenglin Yan is a professor and Vice President of the School of Petrochemical Engineering at Changzhou University in Changzhou, China. He received his PhD from Dalian University of Technology in 2008. In 2011, he became a staff scientist and a group leader at the Institute for Integrative Nanoscience at the Leibniz Institute in Dresden (Germany). His primary research interests focus on electrochemical energy storage and conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Ammonia (NH3) is a multifunctional compound that is an important feedstock for the agricultural and pharmaceutical industries and attractive energy storage medium. At present, NH3 synthesis is highly dependent on the conventional Haber–Bosch process that operates under harsh conditions, which consumes large quantities of fossil fuels and releases a large amount of carbon dioxide. As an alternative, electrosynthesis is a prospective method for producing NH3 under normal temperature and pressure conditions. Although electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction to ammonia has attracted considerable attentions, the low solubility of N2 and high N≡N cracking energy render the achievements of high NH3 yield rate and Faradaic efficiency difficult. Nitrate and nitrite (NO x −) are common N-containing pollutants. Due to their high solubilities and low dissociation energy of N=O, NO x − are ideal raw materials for NH3 production. Therefore, electrocatalytic NO x − reduction to NH3 (eNO x RR) is a prospective strategy to simultaneously realise environmental protection and NH3 synthesis. This review offers a comprehensive understanding of the thriving eNO x RR under ambient conditions. At first, the popular theory and mechanism of eNO x RR and a summary of the measurement system and evaluation criteria are introduced. Thereafter, various strategies for developing NO x − reduction catalysts are systematically presented and discussed. Finally, the challenges and possible prospects of electrocatalytic NO x − reduction are outlined to facilitate energy-saving and environmentally friendly large-scale synthesis of NH3 in the future.
